@mlok-nokia when the issue is hit, there are no reboot-cause json files in `/host/reboot-cause/history/` ?

> @mlok-nokia when the issue is hit, there are no reboot-cause json files in `/host/reboot-cause/history/` ?

Correct. When the issue happens.  File /host/reboot-cause/previous-reboot-cause reference to a file in /host/reboot-cause/history/  which doesn't exist.   This PR is to correct the problem which already happened  and allow determine-reboot-cause to run success.
@prgeor could you please help to review or assign someone to do so?
@Junchao-Mellanox can you elaborate more on this `This implementation makes sonic-mgmt test case not so stable`

> @Junchao-Mellanox can you elaborate more on this `This implementation makes sonic-mgmt test case not so stable`

Currently, sonic-mgmt has a test case like this:
1. mock something, e.g. PSU high temperature
2. wait 70 seconds 
3. check redis database and verify healthd put PSU high temperature error to STATE DB

The case failed intermittently because sometimes 70 seconds is not enough. If we introduce a time compensation to healthd main loop, healthd loop interval will be more accurate and 70 seoncds is enough. BTW, time compensation is a common way in sonic.

@jcaiMR 

> Then isc-dhcp will send 4 offers to client, suppose Vlan1000 Offer RX should be 4 and Vlan Offer TX should always same as Vlan Offer RX which is also 4.
But here the counter is 1/1 which seems not right. Same as ACK.

This is the original dhcpmon counter count as mentioned in the below reply. 

> Then isc-dhcp will send 4 offers to client, suppose Vlan1000 Offer RX should be 4 and Vlan Offer TX should always same as Vlan Offer RX which is also 4.
But here the counter is 1/1 which seems not right. Same as ACK.

This is the counter after running dhcp_relay default test from sonic-mgmt. I ran it with the original dhcpmon and dhcpmon after dualtor change. It sends one packet of each, and the request count is the total count of dhclient receiving ack and sending the response and the test sending a mock request packet. Not sure why Ack does not match.

reviews.body:
A little bit confused about the testing result:

Dhcpmon counter after this PR:
[ PortChannel104- Current rx/tx] Discover: 0/ 1, Offer: 1/ 0, Request: 0/ 3, ACK: 1/ 0
[ PortChannel103- Current rx/tx] Discover: 0/ 1, Offer: 1/ 0, Request: 0/ 3, ACK: 1/ 0
[ PortChannel102- Current rx/tx] Discover: 0/ 2, Offer: 1/ 0, Request: 0/ 6, ACK: 1/ 0
[ PortChannel101- Current rx/tx] Discover: 0/ 0, Offer: 1/ 0, Request: 0/ 0, ACK: 1/ 0
[ Vlan1000- Current rx/tx] Discover: 1/ 0, Offer: 1/ 1, Request: 3/ 0, ACK: 1/ 1
[ Agg-Vlan1000- Current rx/tx] Discover: 1/ 4, Offer: 1/ 1, Request: 3/ 12, ACK: 1/ 1

Here 1 Discover from client, with 4 help address, 4 Discover relayed to DHCP server, due to ECMP port channel tx counters = 1+1+2+0, which is right.
Then 4 servers give 4 Offer and send to portchannel interfaces, Portchannel Offer RX counter = 1+1+1+1
Then isc-dhcp will send 4 offers to client, suppose Vlan1000 Offer RX should be 4 and Vlan Offer TX should always same as Vlan Offer RX which is also 4.
But here the counter is 1/1 which seems not right. Same as ACK.

Another thing, is this testing under a real client DHCP online procedural ? The Request counter seems not match with ACK counter.

> Why changing IPv6 helper table name?

Hi @yxieca, this is not table name in db, it's just test case name. Table name is in line 6, line 22 of mock_config.py ("DHCP_RELAY") which is not changed. Change in line 3 is shown in test results which is in bold below:

test_show_dhcp_relay.py::test_show_dhcp_relay_0_**ipv6_with_header** <- ../../../../usr/local/lib/python3.9/dist-packages/pyfakefs/fake_filesystem_unittest.py PASSED [ 92%]
test_show_dhcp_relay.py::test_show_dhcp_relay_1_**ipv6_without_header** <- ../../../../usr/local/lib/python3.9/dist-packages/pyfakefs/fake_filesystem_unittest.py PASSED [ 94%]
test_show_dhcp_relay.py::test_show_dhcp_relay_2_**ipv4_with_header** <- ../../../../usr/local/lib/python3.9/dist-packages/pyfakefs/fake_filesystem_unittest.py PASSED [ 97%]
test_show_dhcp_relay.py::test_show_dhcp_relay_3_**ipv4_without_header** <- ../../../../usr/local/lib/python3.9/dist-packages/pyfakefs/fake_filesystem_unittest.py PASSED [100%]

I think such a change is more reasonable and understandable.
@yaqiangz Any reason we use “helper” for ipv4 and “destination” for ipv6 ?

> @yaqiangz Any reason we use “helper” for ipv4 and “destination” for ipv6 ?

Helpers are DHCPv4 only concept, DHCPv6 it use relay destination.

> > @yaqiangz Any reason we use “helper” for ipv4 and “destination” for ipv6 ?
> 
> Helpers are DHCPv4 only concept, DHCPv6 it use relay destination.

Thanks, i understand we use this terminology is SONiC. Could you point me towards an RFC or something where this terminology is used/defined. I tried to search but couldn't find it.

> > > @yaqiangz Any reason we use “helper” for ipv4 and “destination” for ipv6 ?
> > 
> > 
> > Helpers are DHCPv4 only concept, DHCPv6 it use relay destination.
> 
> Thanks, i understand we use this terminology is SONiC. Could you point me towards an RFC or something where this terminology is used/defined. I tried to search but couldn't find it.

helper address is first known as ip helper address (not only for dhcp), it's v4 only concept. Not sure which RFC mentioned it first, it may first mentioned in cisco ios-cli https://www.ciscopress.com/articles/article.asp?p=330807&seqNum=9

reviews.body: Why changing IPv6 helper table name?

> Seems like calling a non-existing script.

Shall I put Cisco platform specific check here:
[[ x$sonic_asic_platform != x"cisco-8000" ]]
@vaibhavhd This change will impact warm-reboot and fast-reboot.
@anamehra What is the impact of this change to fast/warm reboot?

> @anamehra What is the impact of this change to fast/warm reboot?

This should not impact the fast-reboot/warm-reboot. This script is called as part of systemd shutting down all services.
I can add Cisco-8000 specific check to run only on Cisco platforms and also it will execute the script only if present.

I fast-reboot/warm-reboot script calls the syncd_request_shutdown as part of pre-shutdown request. I am working on a change to call this pre-shutdown script there as well to help with warm reboots on Cisco platform.
Hi @abdosi , please rerun the pipeline. I see some issue suggesting Lock testbed failed.
Hi @abdosi , please help with merging this PR.

the design doc says only signing mellanox specific kernel module, wonder why?
the pr needs to provide steps how to build sb-enabled image for other to try it out. otherwise, it would be difficult for community members to check.

> how can we test this SB feature? is there a virtual environment that we can test and validate?

## with a physical device:
1. enable the Secure Boot flag in UEFI.
2. store the public keys in UEFI.
3. build the sonic-buildimage using the Secure Boot flags according to the HLD explanations.
4. manually, check that the boot and init flow works.
5. automation - run the corresponding sonic-mgmt tests. (pointer to sonic-mgmt test should be attached in the HLD description)

In general - a successful secure boot flow is one where you load all kernel modules and nothing fails.

## With a virtual machine:
1. should verify that the VM supports UEFI and supports storing pub keys in the DB and Secure Boot UEFI flag.
In addition - currently the Linux is pulling the public key from the UEFI DB in order to verify the sbsign output for each secure boot component. The VM would have to support this basic Linux flow.
2. Do steps like a physical device.

> the design doc says only signing mellanox specific kernel module, wonder why?

fix the doc to generic vendor:
`fsroot-vendor_name instead fsroot-mellanox`

> the pr needs to provide steps how to build sb-enabled image for other to try it out. otherwise, it would be difficult for community members to check.

The HLD shows all the steps in general, but I added as per your requested more description in this PR.

> the pr needs to provide steps how to build sb-enabled image for other to try it out. otherwise, it would be difficult for community members to check.

done

> the design doc says only signing mellanox specific kernel module, wonder why?

fixed

Hi @abhishekd0,
Hope all is well, 
we answered all the comments and concerns, can you please approve this PR?
Thanks
David

this pr seems too large, and contains multiple features, can we break this pr into smaller pieces so that it becomes more clear.

for example, the kernel module signing, shim signing, we can break into separate pr.
the instruction to repro seems not clear enough, we need more detailed instructions on how to build/how to verify especially for in a virtual environment.

> this pr seems too large, and contains multiple features, can we break this pr into smaller pieces so that it becomes more clear.
> 
> for example, the kernel module signing, shim signing, we can break into separate pr.

the signing flow has dependencies between the different boot loaders, this flow name is "chain of trust", so breaking it into small PRs will create build issues and problems to test the commits separately.

As a result of that, if better to code in one PR.

> the instruction to repro seems not clear enough, we need more detailed instructions on how to build/how to verify especially for in a virtual environment.

There are instructions on how to build the sonic image with secure boot feature in this PR description and in the HLD, 
About the verification, there is also descriptions in the PR. 
pls let me know which steps are not clear.
about virtualization, you can test the feature in the same way as a physical device, you need to have a VM that supports UEFI with a secure boot feature and support to add certificates to the UEFI DB.
@davidpil2002 I have added to this branch the key and certificate mounts we discussed about

@lguohan , @rlhui can you please go over the changes following the review comments or let us know who is expected to review?
we would like to close the loop of the feature and backport it to 202211 asap.

But this was not part of the HLD
So if this is now a new req I suggest it should be handled as a separate work on top of the existing one

In slave.mk<https://nam11.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fsonic-net%2Fsonic-buildimage%2Fpull%2F12692%23discussion_r1113797873&data=05%7C01%7Cliatg%40nvidia.com%7Cb28c79b9c15c4438d2c108db1487a6fe%7C43083d15727340c1b7db39efd9ccc17a%7C0%7C0%7C638126345079198027%7CUnknown%7CTWFpbGZsb3d8eyJWIjoiMC4wLjAwMDAiLCJQIjoiV2luMzIiLCJBTiI6Ik1haWwiLCJXVCI6Mn0%3D%7C3000%7C%7C%7C&sdata=OPJeLjbSILO93V7sDWQ6B53IuKBIND%2FqDF8tu2ZaSsc%3D&reserved=0>:

> @@ -376,6 +376,10 @@ $(info "USE_NATIVE_DOCKERD_FOR_BUILD"    : "$(SONIC_CONFIG_USE_NATIVE_DOCKERD_FO
 $(info "SONIC_USE_DOCKER_BUILDKIT"       : "$(SONIC_USE_DOCKER_BUILDKIT)")
 $(info "USERNAME"                        : "$(USERNAME)")
 $(info "PASSWORD"                        : "$(PASSWORD)")
+$(info "SECURE_UPGRADE_MODE"             : "$(SECURE_UPGRADE_MODE)")
+$(info "SECURE_UPGRADE_DEV_SIGNING_KEY"  : "$(SECURE_UPGRADE_DEV_SIGNING_KEY)")
+$(info "SECURE_UPGRADE_DEV_SIGNING_CERT" : "$(SECURE_UPGRADE_DEV_SIGNING_CERT)")
+$(info "SECURE_UPGRADE_PROD_SIGNING_TOOL": "$(SECURE_UPGRADE_PROD_SIGNING_TOOL)")


SECURE_UPGRADE_DEV_SIGNING_KEY is a secure-boot key, Kernel module signing may use the same key or a different key. If the build system exposes SECURE_UPGRADE_KO_SIGNING_KEY then the vendor can have the flexibility to choose a separate key or pass both variables with the same keys.

—
